moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 a6 4. Ba4 Nf6 5. O-O Be7 6. Re1 b5 7. Bb3 O-O 8. h3
1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 a6 4. Ba4 Nf6 5. O-O Be7 6. Re1 b5 7. Bb3 O-O 8. h3 Bb7 9. d3 h6 10. Nc3 Bc5
comment:
Up to now, 10 ..Re8 or ..d6 has been the only moves here.  However, Leko's
move fits in with his Archangel\Moeller set-up with ..Bb7.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 a6 4. Ba4 Nf6 5. O-O Be7 6. Re1 b5 7. Bb3 O-O 8. h3 Bb7 9. d3 h6 10. Nc3 Bc5 11. a4 b4 12. Ne2 Na5 13. Ba2 d5 14. Nxe5 dxe4 15. d4 Ba7 16. Be3 Bd5
comment:
Common sense, really. 
Leko has to do something about the knight on a5, and his move (challenging the
Shirov's strong, white-squared bishop) makes way for the knight to come back
into the game via b7 or c6.

comment:
They have a saying in Spain: "Tirar la casa la por ventana."
(Throwing the house out of the window).  Fortunately for Shirov, Leko throws
the house back through the window!
